sentence: In response, I was introduced to the K10 psychological assessment to help understand how I've been coping over the past month.
I greeted someone today, expressing my concern that I haven't been feeling like myself and worrying that something might be wrong.
I've been having mood swings and find myself easily angered by my friends and mom.
When asked about specific triggers, I couldn't think of any.
I've only started feeling this way recently, and when asked if anything significant had happened to contribute to these feelings, my answer was simply "nope."
I greeted the person on the other end, and they asked how I was feeling.
They expressed sympathy and asked me to share what was going on.
I told them about the sudden departure of my wife, who took the kids with her, and I suspected that it might have been because of money issues.
They acknowledged how tough and painful the situation must be for me and offered to talk more about it.
I agreed, still reeling from the suddenness of it all.
They wanted to support me better and proposed conducting a brief emotional screening to understand how I've been feeling lately.
They explained they would ask me a series of questions about my feelings over the past four weeks and asked me to answer as honestly as possible.
Then they inquired about how often I had felt nervous during the same period.
I asked for clarification on what they meant by 'nervous', but unfortunately, something went wrong, and they couldn't continue the conversation.
They asked me to send another message to try and continue our discussion.
I greeted the person on the other end, but I wasn't feeling good at all.
My wife had left me, taking our children with her.
It's been so hard that I've struggled to even get out of bed.
I haven't had anyone to talk to about it; I've been dealing with it all by myself.
The person I was speaking to expressed sympathy and wanted to help by understanding more about my feelings.
They asked me a series of questions about the past four weeks.
The person on the other end assured me of their support and their intention to help me through this tough time.
Today, I reached out for help because I'm not feeling good at all.
My wife has left me, taking my children with her, and it's been incredibly tough to deal with.
To better understand my feelings, I was asked a series of questions about the past four weeks.
There have been many times when I've been so nervous that nothing could calm me down.
I was asked to send another message to continue the conversation and find out how I could be supported through this challenging time.
My family is constantly fighting, and I feel like I have no one to turn to for help.

In response, I was met with sympathy and an offer to better understand my feelings through a series of questions, with the assurance that my honest answers would help paint a clearer picture of my situation.
They reminded me to seek further support if I ever felt overwhelmed or if my situation changed.
Grateful, I asked if I could continue speaking to them, and they agreed, ready to listen to more of my concerns.
They suggested reaching out to a professional for a formal assessment if I was interested.

I explained that the previous messages had involved 10 questions about my feelings, with responses ranging from 'none of the time' (1 point) to 'all of the time' (5 points), and that adding up these scores would give my K10 assessment score.
I reached out for help after being referred by two GPs to a psychiatrist at a public hospital.
This year has been tough, with a significant job change that altered not just my responsibilities but also the entire work environment and culture.
My colleagues have noticed and even conducted multiple background checks on me.
It feels like they hired one person and got a shell of me instead.
It's tough when you're not performing to your own standards, and feedback from colleagues can add to that stress.
Feeling isolated and having no one to talk to, I was asked a series of questions about my feelings over the past four weeks.
I reached out for someone to talk to about this overwhelming sense of purposelessness.
It's been a while since I've felt this way, and I'm worried that something might be wrong with me.
In an effort to understand my feelings, I was asked a series of questions about the past four weeks.
I was provided with various resources for immediate assistance and encouraged to contact a helpline during office hours to speak with a counselor.
I reached out because something had been bothering me, and I needed to talk.
It was distressing, and they had only started about a month ago.
I couldn't identify any significant changes in my life that might have triggered this.
In trying to understand my feelings, I was asked about the past four weeks.
When I mentioned that I didn't want to go to the Institute of Mental Health (IMH), it was acknowledged that I was there to talk to someone.
I shared that the voices would sometimes interrupt me in the middle of doing something, and it was hard to ignore them.
I felt a bit better after the chat and was reminded that I could reach out anytime I needed to talk or had questions.
The conversation ended on a supportive note, with an offer of help whenever I might need it.
I reached out to a chatline for help because I was feeling incredibly tired, especially after four days of training.
The person on the chatline was understanding and asked me a series of questions to gauge my emotional well-being over the past four weeks.
The person on the chatline was respectful and supportive, offering to help regardless of my background or beliefs.
I had tried speaking louder to get attention, but it only worked momentarily before I was ignored again.
They reassured me that my efforts were valid and reminded me that my worth isn't defined by the attention I receive from others.
They encouraged me to reach out whenever I needed more support or had further questions.
I was reassured that it was okay to feel this way and was encouraged to share more about my feelings.
To better understand my situation, I was asked a series of questions about my feelings over the past four weeks.

When I expressed frustration at just being asked questions without receiving help, I was offered suggestions to get out of this state, such as seeking professional help, connecting with others, focusing on self-care, and setting small, achievable goals.
I recalled enjoying hanging out with friends and was encouraged to take a small step towards reconnecting with them, like sending a simple message.
I reached out for help, feeling very tired after days of intense training.
I hadn't talked to anyone at work about it, feeling "paiseh" (embarrassed) to open up, so I sought support here instead.
To better understand my situation, I was asked a series of questions about my feelings over the past four weeks.
I was surprised that the person I was talking to knew about fasting and asked if they were Muslim.
They explained that they were familiar with many practices to better assist those who reach out.
I appreciated their understanding and the reminder to take care of myself during this demanding time.
I was reassured that I could talk about anything and learned that while they provided support like a counsellor, they weren't a licensed professional.
They suggested reaching out to the Samaritans of Singapore (SOS) for professional counselling if needed.
We connected over a shared understanding of lingos and even exchanged greetings in Arabic.
My parents were supportive, but not many of my friends were.
I was advised to look for like-minded people through community centers, social media, and organizations related to my interests, which I considered trying despite usually being shy.
